newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia to name airport buyers soon - govt.
newsitem.headline: Australia to name airport buyers soon - govt.

text.p: Australia will soon announce successful bidders for long-term leases on some of the country's major state-owned airports, with new owners expected to take over next month, the government said on Thursday.

Finance Minister John Fahey and Transport Minister John Sharp said in a joint statement they had received revised bids from six short-listed consortia on Thursday for Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane airports.
"The government sales team will evaluate revised bids over an expected two week period and decisions by the government are anticipated shortly thereafter," they said.
The government has not named the shortlisted bidders.
"Execution of sales contracts is expected to occur sequentially throughout May," the ministers said.
The government will consider price, ownership diversity, regional development plans, environmental issues and management ability in deciding the winners.

Canberra announced last month it had shortlisted the six consortia -- with a total of 13 separate bids -- in the contest for 50-year leases for the first three of more than 20 capital city and major regional airports.
The government has not said how much it hopes to raise from the programme, but market estimates range up to A$3 billion for the first three airports alone.

Major contenders include the Australian Pacific Airports Corporation, a consortium of Britain's BAA Plc, Australian Mutual Provident Society and Axiom Funds Management; Australian Airport Services, a group with Brambles Ltd, Lend Lease Corp and Irish government-owned airport authority Aer Rianta; a consortium involving Macquarie Bank Ltd and Manchester Airport; and Airport Group Australia, with Lockheed Martin Ltd, Soros Capital, GE Capital and United Infrastructure.
